newsitem.title: UK: OPTIONS - Gilt vols steady as futures fluctuate.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Gilt vols steady as futures fluctuate.

text.p: Implied volatility of gilt options traded on LIFFE failed to budge on Friday, despite a drop in the underlying futures this week after a poor showing on a long-term auction, traders said.
Investors bought calls to get long of gilt options at out-of-the-money strikes on a view that the market would move higher.
But there was also strong interest in selling vol ahead of the Bank holiday weekend in Britain. Markets will be closed on Monday.

Thursday's fall sent gilt futures almost back to levels seen before a sharp rally at the beginning of May when the new Labour government shifted the decision on interest rates to the Bank of England (BOE).
That decision was seen positive for the gilt market as the more independent BOE was expected to have a firmer grip on inflation.
But analysts said continued evidence on the robustness of the economy was fuelling expectations of an interest rate hike soon.
Thursday's auction of paper due 2021 attracted cover of just 1.29 times with a lengthy yield tail, further weighing on sentiment.
But on Friday gilts recovered some of their losses with the June futures traded on LIFFE up 17/32 basis points at 112-13 by 1400 GMT, and compared with the lows on Thursday of 111-21.
In options, activity centred on July calls on September futures.
"In the short term people view that there is more positive feeling in the market," said one trader at a UK investment house.
"It's mainly been upside buying (in options)," he added.
A call spread on July 113-00/114-00 strikes grabbed the biggest slice of the day's volume, traders said.
But volatilities of out-of-the-money calls stood around 7.5 percent, broadly unchanged from Thursday.

In the short sterling market, volatilities eased in line with the market's recent rangebound tone, traders said. The December out-of-the-money strikes traded at around 10 percent, down 1.15 points from Thursday.
March and December calls at 93.75 and 93.50 strikes on respectively on March and December futures saw moderate business.
"Everyone sold the vols before the long weekend," said one trader on the LIFFE floor.
"The vols are not high but I think they will go even lower," he added.
September short sterling futures traded two basis points up at 93.19 on Friday.
